Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Laser Assisted Nanotechnology-Sensor For Cost Effective Use In Fish Processing To Determine Mercury Levels In Fish Flesh Or Other Substances
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will substantially and rapidly increase environmental and food safety by testing the feasibility of using carbon nano-tube covered sensors to electrochemically detect the amount of mercury in substances such as water or fish, by vaporizing a small spot of the substance to determine mercury levels in each sample as it is being processed. The resulting technology will be expanded to detect the amount of other heavy metals and commercialized. The effects of methyl mercury on human health are devastating. This work enables Dahl Natural to bridge the gap for real-time, remote, automated heavy metal testing.

The broader commercial impacts of this research are to enable access to real-time, low cost, accurate measurement of heavy metals in food, water and other substances to 500ppt/L sensitivity. This work will eliminate many unique challenges of in-situ measurement so processes and strategies can be developed to reduce heavy metal contamination. This technology is needed by industries, researchers, government agencies, Tribal groups, and addresses a $1 billion market. Testing takes 2-3 minutes and data from the device can be printed for bar codes, tags or sent electronically to a data base. The cost-savings of this technology is $150.00 per test, estimated at <$1.00 per metal tested.

POR.DRECONTENT:
SBIR Title: Laser Assisted Nanotechnology-Sensor for Cost Effective Use in Fish Processing to Determine Mercury Levels in Fish Flesh or other Substances.

NSF Category: Nanotechnology, Advanced Materials, and Manufacturing NM/B2

Applicant: Dahl Natural LLC, Arizona State University

PI Anne Schwartz, Co PI:  Vinay Janthakhalli, Jeffrey Labelle

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project has shown proof of concept to substantially and rapidly increase environmental and food safety by real-time testing of mercury using sensors to electrochemically detect the amount of mercury in substances such as unfiltered surface water.   The device developed called the ECM 300 was able to detect low  levels of mercury at 150 ppt /L in just three minutes from unfiltered river water.  A unique mercury specific binding protein was developed and used for the first time on a sensing device.  The protein is patentent pending. The resulting technology will be expanded to detect the amount of other heavy metals and applied to water quality testing and food processing for demonstration and commercialization of the ECM 300. The effects of methyl mercury on human health are devastating. This work enables Dahl Natural to bridge the gap for real-time, remote, automated heavy metal testing to enable safer water and food.

The broader commercial impact of this research is to: enable access to real-time, low cost, accurate measurement of heavy metals in food, water and other substances to 150 ppt/L sensitivity.  This work will eliminate many unique challenges of field and real-time measurement of metals in food or water. This will allow companies and researchers to have enough information to develop or adjust processes and strategies to reduce heavy metal contamination.  This technology is needed by industries, researchers, government agencies, Tribal groups, and addresses a $1 billion market. Testing takes 2-3 minutes and data from the device can be printed for bar codes, tags or sent electronically to a data base. The cost-savings of this technology is up to $150.00 per test, estimated at <$1.00 per mean metal test.  The hand-held instrument is designed with recyclable disposable sensor array panels for ease of use.


Last Modified: 12/14/2011
Modified by: Anne M Schwartz
